What happens when infinite energy is applied to an object that can't move?
Well if the parts can't move it can't explode.
But that immovable object is still an object absorbing energy, so I'm assuming it changes state.
That immovable mountain becomes an immovable gas...err plasma...err quark-gluon plasma?
Or does it?

You see, increasing the energy of an object also increases its mass.
And we know that mass warps time-space, slowing down time near that object.
So as you apply more energy to that immovable object, you're slowing down time around it, slowing the rate that energy is applied.

We can see from black hole models that as time-space is warped so strongly, the result functions similarly to as if the time and space variables were flipped.
Instead of everything moving forward in time constantly, and being free to move through space, things are constantly pulled toward the black hole, and capable of changing their frame of reference in time.
You seem to reach a point where applying that force to that immovable object doesn't make sense in our understanding of physics.

Seems the immovable object wins.
Or maybe more correctly, time-space around it loses.
But that's just a theory, a way past my bed time theory.
Thanks for coming to my Ted Talk.

I imagined when I was younger that an immovable object would stop in space, but seeing as everything moves around it, would appear to be moving. It would act like a wall in ocean currents, no matter its size.

Meanwhile an unstoppable object would mean it could never stop moving and could continuously increase its energy and speed up while never reaching zero. Which would have it moving with you in space and able to increase its potential energy from its conception.

So I looked at an immovable object as a universal scale object unaffected by relative, while unstoppable is determined by initial relative factors until it either surpasses relative or falls beneath it to reach a similar, but never the same energy loss as an immovable.

A pin in space time versus an object surfing its waves.

But I suppose that doesn't make a lot of sense. An unstoppable object can mean it never loses energy or speed as well.

Anyway, That's my ramble.

This is an old question, and one that has people doing all sorts of mental gymnastics in redefining the terms in order to come up with some sort of sensible answer.

But it is actually incredibly simple. Philosophical redefinitions aside, we have two things:

A) An unstoppable force
B) an immovable object.

Think about A, now. Any force is unstoppable in that it carries on - whatever energy the force carries is merely transported from one object to another. If a force does not 'move' an object, it will surely raise its temperature. But though this is physically correct, it's clearly not in the spirit of the question. The question wants us to break our brains in overcoming a paradox. So let's define an 'unstoppable force', as per the question, as something that will move something else, regardless of the second object's state, mass or size. Right. Now we have an unstoppable force. In order for such a thing to exist, so that it could move absolutely anything, it will require infinite energy. Bear with me for a second...

Let's consider B. An immovable object. That's to say, something that won't budge an inch, regardless of whatever force is applied to it. The only thing that would make it unmovable would be infinite mass, in order for it to have infinite inertia. It doesn't matter how much energy you apply, you will not be able to overcome the inertia of infinite mass. Staying with the spirit of the question, our immovable object won't collapse upon itself to form the biggest black hole ever. It will just sit there, immovable.

Now we apply A to B...

What happens?

Absolutely sweet-blue nothing. Can't be done.

The only way for a 'force' (as per the question) to be 'unstoppable', would be for it to have infinite energy. And the only way for an object to be 'immovable' would be for it to have infinite mass. Now, we know that mass and energy is the same thing, right? They are interchangeable. Think of mass as 'condensated energy'. If there was an unstoppable force, it would require all the energy of the universe. Every last bit of it. That would include all the energy from all the radiation as well as all the mass of the universe. There would be nothing left with which to assemble the immovable object. If you start with the immovable object, it would require all the mass of the universe, plus all the energy from radiation converted to mass. That would leave nothing for the unstoppable force.

In other words, an immovable object and an unstoppable force would both require every scrap of energy and matter in the universe, and thus would be the same thing. And there can only be one of them. The question, then, boils down to what would happen if the universe runs into itself?

So I think I have a different solution to that problem. I'm going to propose that two infinitely massive objects colliding would bounce of each other. Now hear me out:

The part with F=ma I agree with. If you have a finite force you cannot accelerate the object.
However:
An infinitely massive object with a velocity will have an infinite kinetic energy. (By E=(1/2)*m*v^2)
That means it can do an infinite amount of work. (W=F*d)
=> inf = F*d = inf*d; provided d is finite (it's negligible then).
Therefore we can apply an infinite amount of force on an object.

Now the question is if an infinite amount of force can budge our object(s). (F/m = a => inf/inf = a)
So really the question is what infinity divided by infinity is. This is where I start with Hilbert's Hotel:

Hilbert's Hotel, as I'm sure you know, has infinitely many rooms. So if an infinite amount of guests arrive, we can stuff all in an individual room. Question: Is Hilbert's Hotel full?
Assume we get another infinite amount of guests. We can then tell everyone with a room to double their room number and take this new one as their room. Then we will have a new infinite amount of rooms to fit everyone in.
Therefore: Hilbert's Hotel wasn't full the first time.
This means for every guest there must be more than one room => inf/inf > 1.

That's enough to prove my point, but we can go further.
The thing is that this process is infinitely repeatable, meaning I can stuff an infinite amount of infinite guests in there. => inf/inf = inf
(Incidentally we also proved now that inf^2 = inf and therefore that inf^n = inf)

So after F=ma: inf=inf*a => inf/inf = a
and inf/inf = inf
The acceleration is in fact infinite. This even means that the objects should shoot themselves away at an infinite amount of acceleration meaning they will pass the speed of light instantly.

All this to say, we shouldn't have infinite mass and not do calculations with infinity in the first place.
But it was fun most certainly!

PS: Thanks for reading, have a good day!

You were thinking of question from a physical standpoint rather than from this standpoint: If we define an immovable object as something that cannot move from the point in space where it resides, no matter how much force is applied to it, and an unstoppable force as something that will never decelerate no matter how much something pushed back on it, and both objects are indestructible, it becomes a paradox. An immovable object and an unstoppable force cannot exist simultaneously. That is because for an object to be immovable, there would have to be able to stop any force, but for an unstoppable force to exist it would have to be able to move any object. That includes the immovable object, but that doesn’t work because it’s immovable. They can’t exist simultaneously by definition. If an unstoppable force exists then there can’t be such a thing as an object it can’t move and vice versa

Iain Banks solution in his book Walking on Glass:

The unstoppable force stops, the immovable object moves.

I think that "solution" is 200% wrong.

Unstoppable force means NOTHING can stop it. Not even the entire universe. This means the force is on the order of "maybe not exactly not infinite but still ridiculously high" levels of energy.



Unmovable object has a similar "nigh infinite" component to it.

So, my own take on the solution to the paradox:

The unstoppable force doesn't stop.
The immovable object doesn't move.

They simply pass through each other exactly like the video poster says.

However, my own take on the "pass through each other" is a bit more complex:

They apparently pass through each other, but at no single point do both objects occupy the same space.

What actually happens is this instead:

It is not a "ghost forms" type of collision. The force and object can both remain solid and impenetrable to each other. But when they collide, without ANY slowdown, the energies unleashed at so incredibly high, that they end up creating extra spacetime. After all, for any given Plank-size Plank-time quantum bit of spacetime, there is a maximum energy it can contain, so any extra energy beyond that must go somewhere else and/or somewhere else.

So the unstoppable force and immovable object collision creates new spacetime. The end result is akin to saying that the unstoppable force goes "around" the immovable object, and the exact same thing happen for the immovable object it also goers "around" the unstoppable force, but none of them are actually deformed in any way. Rather, it is the spacetime around them (in fact right at their surface where the collision occurs) that gets so extremely warped out of normal proportions, that for the far observers both seem to pass through each other.

Probably along with visuals showing that the spacetime near those objects is super extra deformed. Kinda like how light can bend a lot around a black hole. But the force and object themselves would remain unaffected.

Of course, any scientist nearby would probably be vaporized by the amount of energy released by such a collision. Enough to warp spacetime to the max, sure, but still nowhere near enough to slow down the unstoppable force or accelerate the immovable object, not even by one tiny itsy bitsy Plank unit.

As I thought more of this, this video was not done completely correct. It's not a question of acceleration, like you want us to believe, but the concept of momentum. As a refresher, momentum is mass times velocity (M x V). In the video, you mention that the mass of each object is infinite (only way this would work). In the case of the immovable object, the momentum is equal zero (M = infinite, velocity = 0). For the unstopple object, the mass, again, is infinite, but the velocity is constant.
So how would it work so that momentum of zero would react to a momentum of infinite? You just chickened out that they would pass through each other. You'll need to dive much deeper in this case guy.

While this is a neat thought experiment it misses some important factors. If by "object" it's meant a large object that is composed of a finite amount of atoms it would imply that the atoms / particles itself are "un-acceleratable". So in the end we don't talk about large object but actually small objects. Because if the un-acceleratable property comes from the fact that it's just infinitely large we have several issues. First an infinitely large object requires infinitely amount of space. Apart from that if those objects would collide and they are composed of "normal" atoms, the objects would simply disintegrate and spread the collision energy in all directions. Since this disintegration is a continous process (assuming the objects collided at a finite velocity) there would never be an end of this collision process (since an infinite volume moving through space at a finite velocity will never complete passing through that space).

If a particle with infinite mass (i.e. infinite energy) exists, I have no issues with them passing through each other :) It would also solve the issues with the laws of thermodynamics. If they don't interact with anything, they don't transfer any energy.

Another view might be that we have more than our 3 spatial dimensions and there are objects moving in a different higher dimensional axis so our insignificant 3d existance simply can't interact with those objects. They may not have infinite mass or energy, but are simply not stoppable because we can not interact with them in any way. Though that usually means we can't even know they even exist since any kind of observation requires at least some form of interaction :)
This question is meaningless because the two by definition can't coexist in the same environment.

Principle of Relativity:
There is no absolute or "preferred" intertial frame of reference.

Perspective is tantamount to understanding the universe.

One perspective, for example, is when we look up to the sky and see the Sun traveling across the sky.
So, we presumed, based off a singular perspective, that the Sun revolved around the Earth.
When someone else came with a different perspective, namely some nobody named Kopernicus, and posited that the Earth actually revolves around the Sun, how much resistance was he met with?
Like you would resist what I posit, I also being a nobody?

Historically, it is the secular perspective which challenges the vernacular that ends up being right.
Yet, why do humans, as a whole, insist on believing the vernacular of their time is immutable?

How often was the vernacular immutable?
Never.

So, why is it, despite all the countless years, we as humans STILL resist the outside opinion?

Instead of looking at the the cultures of the past as a purely anthropologic perspective, how many look at the past with the scrutiny of a psychological perspective?
What were they thinking?
What drove their thoughts, their patterns?
What made the people of the time resist information that was ultimately the more correct information?

Why is it the higher one thinks of themselves, the greater their refusal to admit oversight?

How many physicists understand human behavioral sciences?
How many psychologists understand physics?

Having worked in medicine, you would be aghast to understand that are scholastic establishments, instead of teaching true understanding of the grasp of concept, have pre-packaged information in segments.

A Cardiologist, therefore, will be specialized with the Heart, but may not have barely higher than the basic grasp of Neurology.
A Pharmacist may understand how all the medicines interact within a patients body, but what do they know about Archeology?

"But that isn't their job."

Yeah, way to sound like the Brawndo segment of Idiocracy.

Let me clarify:
The understanding of the quanta is the pursuit of understanding the subatomic particles that comprise the atoms that form the chemicals, the same chemicals that formed biological components of which fauna and flora consist of, we, as humans, consist of these same chemicals.

Just as all that is tied together, so, too, are the functions of all of reality.
The pursuit of a unifying theory is misleading, as the Universe is ALREADY unified.

It is our understanding that does not correlate with reality, not reality that does not corelate.

"The universe is weird, janky."
No, the current ideology is janky.
It is like long division, parts may be right, but the product is still wrong, so we must go back and revise.

It is the ideology that needs to be viewed with skepticism and possibly readily dismissed, not the new ideas.
Even if the new ideas are WRONG, it allows us to rule out what it isn't, which therefore reduces the pool of what it actually is.

Yet, why is it we do not do that?
Why is it we must adhere to a fallacious established belief until forced, with humility, to admit something or someone else was right?

Oh, and wouldn't the example of Neutrinos passing through matter be a case of an unstoppable force meeting an immovable object, as it just passes through with no sign of intertia?

My contention is this historically futile and phyrric adherence we humans exhibit to the established belief of our time.
This is literally the epitome of being closed minded.
Yet what closed minded person literally helped pioneer the understandings we have today?
None.
Rather, they were the hurdles that prevented such.

Just as we look back and think, "Oh, what fools they were", will the future people not think the same of those unwilling to open the door for new concepts?

I have a saying,
"It is better to give someone the benefit of the doubt or believe they are possibly more capable in than you, and allow them to prove you wrong than it is to deny them, refusing to believe they may understand or be more capable than you...and allow them to prove you wrong."

The answer is simple. If there actually were an unstoppable force that met an immovable object, the direction in which the unstoppable force is traveling would simply change,  up, down, right or left, and it would continue on it's way. And because it is an unstoppable force, it would not slow down while changing direction. If it did slow down, no matter how imperceptible, that would imply that it can eventually be stopped. If it can be slowed down a little, then it can be slowed down a lot. And if it can be slowed down a lot, then it can be stopped. But it is unstoppable. So it would make this directional change without slowing down, even slightly, and it's speed of travel would remain the same. Every time it met an immovable object, it would simply make directional change, and keep going.

This ignores the point about relativity because "unstoppable" in the context of the question does not mean relative, it simply means a force which for the context of the question cannot be stopped, to bring the matter of speed into the question is missing the point.

He loses me when he jumps to the "that means the unstoppable force's velocity cannot be changed. I think this explanation overshoots the mark of what this age old question poses. What happens when an immovable object meets an unstoppable force? There is no such thing as an immovable object in this universe if enough force (to move it) is applied -- and there is no such thing as an unstoppable force if enough resistance is applied (to stop if from moving). Bringing in the concept of relativity is irrelevant to what I think the question is posing. As a practical matter I cannot move a mountain so as far as I am concerned that is an immovable object. I also cannot put my hand up and stop a cruise missile in flight, so that's how I understand the question. This objective thought out "scientific"explanation completely misses it in my unscientific opinion. LOL In short, the force that is strongest between the two will win and I'm good with that.

Immovable object and unstoppable force are all about switching between different inertial reference frame. From one object's reference frame, it is the immovable object while the other object is the unstoppable force and vice versa from the other object's reference frame. This is an interesting answer. Isaac Asimov's answer was that the question is moot, because an unstoppable force and an immovable object can't coexist in the same universe. If there exists an unstoppable force, then that means there's no object it can't move, thus there can be no immovable object. If there exists an immovable object, then that means there's no force it can't stop, thus there can be no unstoppable force.

Bullshit man

This is not a question of perspective. ALL things are in motion. Even the EXACT center of the entire universe is probably moving, at least in rotation. Citing perspective is a cop-out. Whether a joke or a philosophical debate or an earnest question, do not diminish it with this sidestep to the question.

The question is, in order to remove ambiguity, "What happens when something that is absolutely static - all other things flowing around it, not through it or able to act upon it if in collision with it - meets an absolutely energetic force directed at it and only it, specifically?".

Now, I've made the joke "The universe moves." about this, saying that the action pushes the universe, but that is a joke. Really, the three answers I can come up with are Nothing, Everything, and Bounce. The Nothing refers to the Force's energy switching from Kinetic Energy to Potential Energy, still absolute in force but otherwise immobile. The Everything refers to the Force and the Object being fundamentally incompatible and causing absolutely chaos through a powerful release of matter and energy. And Bounce is on the off-chance that the Object is the way it is because it's reflective and dense, like Vibranium.

And that, ladies and gentlemen, is how you answer a question.

Immovable object vs unstoppable force: "Immovable" and "unstoppable" cancels itself out. As a results the immovable object becomes a simply "standing still " object, and the unstoppable force becomes simply a "moving force". Therefore both, the object and the force can move in the direction the moving force is moving. "To every action, there's an equal and opposite reaction". Why unstoppable and immovable cancels itself out is due to the fact that "the best" can only be one.

∞In the case of unstoppable force vs. an immovable object, it is safe to say that nothing can stop the force, however the force is able to be broken, and that the immovable object cannot be broken. The reason being, that if the object breaks, then the atoms within the immovable object will have to separate or move.


∞This cannot work, since the object is immovable, whatever it is made out of will have to stay together infinitely. On the other hand, the unstoppable force can be either broken or exploded when it hits the immovable object, or it can either go straight through it. It can also break into pieces, and the particles that it broke into, can keep on moving on forever.


∞The only real option, is the immovable object, since or cannot be broken or smashed, while the unstoppable force still can. There is also to ponder what elements is the force made out of, or what elements, is the object made out of, this too must be considered. – Isaiah Murray🧠∞🌌

Another interpretation is that an unmovable object is an object with infinite momentum. Having infinite momentum would be the same as being unacceratable in the same direction as your momentum since force is nothing more than increasing or decreasing momentum over time. infinite momentum + finite momentum from force = still infinite momentum.

Though then the amount of kinetic energy is also infinite (with any mass > 0) because of Ek = 1/2*mv^2 (where m is the rest mass of our object). And, according to e = mc^2 -> m = e/(c^2), this would result in infinite mass again (where m now stands for the mass that the object gains in addition to restmass due to having kinetic energy).

an immovable object has to have infinite mass to be immovable, otherwise the force you put into it would cause a tiny change in velocity.
an unstoppable force has to have infinite velocity, otherwise everything it touches will slow it down a tiny amount.

what would happen is the object of infinite velocity would produce an infinite amount of energy through friction and would put an infinite amount of velocity into the object of infinite mass, this would lead to the object of infinite mass producing an infinite amount of friction as well. this release of energy would be so condensed that the space around the objects would start spitting out particles left and right (just as it does in a particle accelerator) and it would produce enough matter and energy to produce a black hole. this black hole would absorb the object of infinite velocity and the object of infinite mass, becoming infinitely large, producing enough pull upon the universe to collapse it into a singular point.

A thought: objects are mental constructs, and two such "objects" meeting would probably disintegrate into more fundamental components, each of which would retain velocity but possibly change direction. Depending on both the objects' makeup, it may or may not appear as if they passed through each other, with a variable degree of particle scattering. If they are perfect mirror copies of each other, this variable would be at 100% and none of the scattering particles could pass the mirror plane at which they touched, as it would bounce off the opposing object's particle (assuming they are not influenced by unmirrored external forces).

If both objects are somehow indivisible, I would expect the unstoppable force to continue with 1/2 of its energy after hitting a stationary unmovable object (assuming both objects hold equally infinite force), and cease if said unmovable object was moving towards it with the same force (both relative to a third, stationary object).

To people asking "What if a moveable object meets a stoppable object?" Heres the Answer
Ok so let's call the movable one "MA" And stoppable one "SA"
Alright, So to get things going we first need to determine at what speed they have to be in to stop or move. If SA goes at 10kmh and the stoppable moves at 9kmh then MA will move for a slight bit and stop because of friction. If let's say there's no friction or air, like space, Then the 9km from SA will get transferred to MA, And because of this transfer, MA will still not move because I never referred to what exact speed it needs. SA will need 9kmh + the smallest amount of force (at least) to move. SA Will probably transfer lets say 9.1km. Making MA go at 100 meters per hour. Ok, so now the question is here. Let's say MA needs 10kmh to move and MA goes at 10kmh, This is really hard to answer because of the math needed. I theorize that MA Will either move or not move. SA Will definitely come to a stop. We have 2 options, MA Either doesn't move or moves the smallest length possible (1 Planck Length) Or even shorter, As the Planck is a theory and isn't officially known. So I'll let you others figure that out.

I used to imagine a conveyor-belt moving uniform cubes of metal down to meet a chomping/crushing hammer and in this scenario only two universal properties applied absolutely: The metal was impossible to break and the hammer would always perfectly smash everything that it encountered. I used to have fun playing around with ideas like that, tripped up by the paradox. As I got older I realized the question is more or less useless because it's a simple incompatible contradiction that, by definition, could not exist. Years later I learned my childhood thought experiment already had a name :P

Turning an unstoppable force into an immovable object is a boring cop-out.

An unstoppable force is a force which cannot be stopped. What's a force that can be stopped? How about a force that has no effect on a (normal) object's velocity. How could that happen? Let's try static fiction. An unstoppable force is a force that cannot be stopped by static friction. Any large force can be stopped by sufficiently large static friction and a sufficiently large mass. Thus an unstoppable force is an an even larger force, i.e. an infinite force, which cannot be stopped by any finite mass & friction. In F=ma terms, F is infinite. What is the effect of applying an infinite (unstoppable) force to an infinite-mass (immovable) object? F=ma, so infinity = infinity * a, or a = infinity/infinity. Now you've turned a classic physics conundrum into a classic math conundrum, which is where this video seemed to be heading during the first half before taking a left turn into silliness.

Er... the relativistic argument against immovable objects works for acceleration too. Red-shift is reference independent just like motion.

The real answer is that this paradox is fake! Acceleration can never be 0 because 1/infinity no matter how big infinity is, never actually hits 0. The limit of 1/x as x approaches infinity is 0, but if you see the graph of 1/x, you'll know that y=0 is an asymptote. So as much as you'd like to approximate, this phenomenon will never mathematically happen because it's simply impossible for acceleration to ever be 0 no matter how infinite the mass is! Bonus: You can prove 1/infinity is not equal 0 because if you multiply it by infinite, you get 1/ But if you multiply infinity by 0, you get 0! Also, you can prove it by thinking of division conceptually as if you were in elementary school. Think about it ok, dividing something is breaking something into a certain number of pieces. Dividing 1 by infinity is like dividing 1 piece of cake into infinitely small pieces. These pieces, however, still exist. 0 is a sign of non-existence so no matter how much you break these objects into smaller and smaller pieces, they'll still exist! (Don't take this cake analogy super seriously, I know you can't split elementary particles or even strings if you believe in that since that's what you'll get to eventually when splitting a cake but nevertheless, it's something cool to think about conceptually) So to answer the paradox, what happens when an unstoppable force meets an immovable object? We don't know because, by our laws of physics, that phenomenon can never happen. The greatest mistake any physicist can make is approximating that value of 1/infinity of 1/0 through limits. You can approximate everything else, just not these 2 extreme values.

If two infinitely massive objects collide, then the force they exert on each other must also be infinite (non-zero velocity squared multiplied by infinite divided by two means it hits an object with infinite kinetic energy and thus infinite force). And now we have infinity divided by infinity. There are a few possibilities here. Either, that gives you 1 meter per second squared acceleration (start passing through each other, but slow down), 0 meters per second squared acceleration (the video), or infinite acceleration (they bounce off each other instantaneously). Even if you imagine other universes with any physical laws you want, the two can not meet, because of definitions. Because the existence of an unstoppable force implies that no immovable objects exist, and the existence of an immovable object implies that no unstoppable forces exist. So if one exists, the other can not, by definition exist. If the two do meet, that means that either the force is not unstoppable, or the object is not immovable.

Isn't it more fair to say that, as far as calculations are concerned, there is no preferred reference frame? Whether you're calculating an object moving towards you at 100 miles per hour, or yourself moving 100 miles an hour towards an object, the math is the same...but that doesn't mean that running toward an object is really pulling that object towards us. In my humble opinion, relative reference frames hold true for mathematical calculations, but not always as fact when describing WHY an object seems to be moving in a specific reference frame. With that being said, I believe the "unstoppable force" (the infinite mass object that's moving as far as the reference frame of the area the objects are on or in is concerned) would deflect off of the "immovable object" (the infinite mass object stationary to the reference frame of the area the objects are moving through/on top of), or, in a far more fun turn of events, accelerate the area that the immovable object is on so that the immovable object remains stationary to the area it's on. Just my two cents.

No... You make concrete assumptions about 2 hypotheticals. One a hypothetical force and the other a hypothetical object. So, to actually answer the question, let me rephrase it properly, then answer it.

Q: What would happen if a hypothetical irresistible force, met a hypothetical immovable object?
A: One of the hypotheticals would be proven wrong.

Why?
Because it's a hypothetical dichotomy... either the immovable object will be unable to resist the irresistible force, and be moved = immovable object was wrong, or the irresistible force will fail to move the immovable object, meaning the irresistible force was wrong. And no, they will not cancel each other out.

Unstoppable force doesn't mean unstoppable object. It also doesn't mean infinite force. It just means 'unstoppable', which means it'll keep on exerting whether it is 1N or 100N.

Immovable object, on the other hand, means that the object won't move.

Overall, the force will keep on exerting, while the object will stay in its place.

I always looked at this question differently. The only way that an object can be immovable is if it is of an infinite mass so its size must therefore be infinitely large. An unstoppable force must also have infinite momentum. I conclude that the unstoppable force and the immovable object are the same thing by default as they both occupy everything all at once every where leaving neither the room to exist away from each other in the first place. It would be silly to say the object moves since something of an infinitely large size cant have relative movement as it already occupies everywhere at once, there is nowhere to move to. The infinite force means it wont be stopped by the object because by definition it will never end.  Also since there cant be anything outside an infinitely large object then there's nothing for the unstoppable force to be transferred from so it must all exist in the object simultaneously. So I say that an unstoppable force and an immovable object are actually a single thing being very large and full of energy but never amounting to anything at any point of itself in proportion to the rest of itself. I believe that it is both doing nothing and everything at the same time.

What is interesting to me to think about is an infinitely large object would have an infinite gravitational force, but since an infinitely large object cant have a center then the gravitational force must be spread out between each point and equal 0 Gs at each point. So infinite gravity is the same thing as no gravity at all. This also further proves my answer of both the object and the force being the same thing and doing both nothing and everything at the same time as by default one should know that an infinite mass would have infinite gravitational force acting everywhere at the same time. The fact that the mass must go in every direction forever to be infinite in mass means that the gravitational force of each point cancels itself out.

Force carriers aren't "particles" in the traditional sense, instead they refer to quantities of energy moving through a field. Photons are quantities of energy that move through an electromagnetic field and gravitons are quantities of energy moving through a gravitational field.

For example if you flip a rope, a wave of energy moves through the rope. In an analogy with light, the rope is the medium (the EM field) and the moving wave of energy would literally be light itself.

Just because the objects are immovable and unstoppable does not make them unbreakable. Assuming that both of these items are made up of properties that makes both the object and force physically exposed to one another, and if they where to vary in durability, these options may be possible to occur:

1). Neither subject matter has an accurately appointed title, therefore " Unstoppable" and "Immovable" does not, and may never, exist . Either the Unstoppable Force will be stopped, the Immovable Object will be moved, or both subject matter's failures occurs after collision.
[My #2 Theory]

(Even if the Unstoppable Force breaks through the Immovable Object, the simple fact that the Immovable Object can be broken, in any way, proves that the object is not immovable. Matter, that makes up the object, that breaks apart from the object has to travel apart from one another in order to seperate, resulting in a form of movement from the Immovable Object.)

2). Same theory as possibility #1, except both subject matter are also unbreakable. In this situation, there should still result in one, or both subject matters resulting in failure.

(#1. The unbreakable, Unstoppable Force is able to move the unbreakable, Immovable object.

#2. The Unstoppable Force is either stopped or ricochets off of the Immovable Object.

[ In order for a ricochete to take effect, the Force colliding with the Object would have to come to a complete stop in order to redirect the Force's energy resulting in the direction of travel, or however it's explained]

or,

3). The Unstoppable Force is more fragile than the Immovable Object. In this situation, the Unstoppable Force will break upon impact with the Immovable Object. Even if broken into few or many pieces, the Unstoppable Force has the potential to continue movement by using the structure, elements, gravity, (etc.) of the Immovable Object's surface.
[My #1 Theory]

(Though the results of this collision may factually decelerate the speed of the Unstoppable Force, this dosen't mean this force has stopped moving, altogether. This theory would be invalid if any broken, seperated pieces of the Unstoppable Force where to stop moving.)

Imo they would instead annihilate each other. The amount of force involved in a collision is indicative of how much the colliding bodies are deformed. If the force involved is infinite, the level of deformation should also be infinite, since it doesn't make any sense to assume they wouldn't interact. This would suggest that both bodies would completely destroy each other and all mass would become energy, similar to a matter-antimatter annihilation. The products of an exothermic reaction for example have less net mass than their reactants, and similarly a nuclear reaction produces energy in proportion to a mass defect given by E=mc^2. This situation is also a physical reaction, and should therefore produce heat, sound and light energy. The amount of mass that becomes energy should equal 100% of all the mass that was involved, which was infinite. So a collision of two such objects should therefore produce a black hole, given that's what you get from an infinite amount of energy/mass in one spot.

This video oversimplified in order to give a simple answer.

Imagine a round shot at short range to a target. Acceleration is not infinite because that doesn't really exist, but high enough for our mind to comprehend. Now compare a paper target vs shooting at kevlar. At short range the object in movement may remain in movement depending on what it hit and not on the mass of the round or the target.

Then there is the possibility of changing the direction of the object in movement. If you use a mirror you can change the direction of a ray of light without really stopping it. Or imagine pumping water through a system of pipes constantly changing direction.

I really like this video. Unfortunately, you made a mistake at the very beginning. You concluded that an immovable object does not exist because of the principle of relativity (POR). However, I believe that you have misunderstood POR. POR says that one person (called the Observer) who can never move must exist, anybody could be this person and it is impossible to experimentally discover who this person is. Let's look at the example you gave at 0:10.

If the Mt. is the Observer, then the man in the rocket is moving while it is perfectly still; if the man is the Observer, then the Mt. is moving while he is perfectly still. In both of these situations someone is not moving. There is a third situation where they are both moving. However, they must be moving relative to a third party, who is the Observer. No matter what, the observer exists. Now that the mistake is corrected, lets return to the question.

The Observer is defined as the only object that is immovable. Lets assume that an object of infinite mass is moving toward the Observer and this object cannot pass through the Observer without effecting him. When the object touches the observer, a gravitational field will instantly appear and pull everything in The Universe in the direction opposite to that which the object was moving. This gravitational field will be infinitely strong because it will stop the object of infinite mass. To properly understand how the object can create an universal gravitational field in this manner requires basic knowledge of the Theory of General Relativity, which I do not have.

The question itself is actually paradoxical. If we have an 'unstoppable' force, by definition, there cannot exist anything that can withstand its force. Therefore, there cannot exist an 'immovable' object, if there exists an unstoppable force. The opposite would also be true. Therefore the question itself is paradoxical and hence there is no answer.

The way I read it is that the paradox is inherently flawed. If in the universe there existed an immovable object, there could not possibly be an unstoppable force, since every possible force would be stopped by the Immovable Object. Likewise, if there was a truly unstoppable force, there could not be such a thing as an immovable object, because every object would be moved by the Unstoppable Force.

here is the true answer.
we must first determine if the object is immovable because it has infinite mass, or infinite inertia. both would require infinite energy to move, which the unstoppable force has, but each would behave differently after the initial interaction.

if the object has infinite mass, then it would require a constant source of infinite energy to continue moving. so the unstoppable force would have just enough energy to move the immovable object a microscopic distance, and then both would stop.

if the object has infinite inertia, then it would still stop the unstoppable force, but would became an unstoppable force itself.

The difficulty with this problem is that we pretty much have to make assumptions about the nature of the immovable object and unstoppable force. In this video, we're assuming that they have these properties because their mass is infinite. Could it be the opposite too? I'm kind of thinking of a sort of massless photon-like particle that can't be absorbed or reflected but that just passes through everything.

So treating these objects like photons (where one is our intertial frame of reference), they'd interfere with each other (as waves do) but there would be no real collision. I guess the answer's the same, though - they pass through each other.
Semantics.
Or they bounce or 'reflect' off of each other, like light against a perfect mirror.

When you come to think about it, that's perhaps the most intuitive answer one could come up with, even without considering all the physics behind it. For both an immovable object and an unstoppable force to exist, they must not interact with each other.

False!
An unstoppable object (U) and an immovable object (I) would both have the same amount of inertia. Exactly infinity! Infinite forces, but equal nonetheless!
Picture U and I as cubes of equal mass, size and shape. Now picture U on a collision course towards I. Due to the forces being equal (U having infinite dynamic inertia, and I having infinite static inertia), they would simply collide and switch properties! U would become I, and I would become U. Much like a Newton's Cradle.
Yes, U would no longer be unstoppable, and I would no longer be immovable.
But Newton doesn't lie! And solid objects certainly don't pass through eachother...

you misunderstand the concept of an immovable object vs an unstoppable force

and immovable object
any object, reguardless of mass, density, volume, size, shape, texture, ect. caught in a fixed position (say 45n 13e) that can not, under any circumstance, be moved from its current fixed position by any outside force no matter what. ever

an unstoppable force
a force, reguardless of its nature, rather it be organic or not, that is set on a constant path at a constant speed (say 100 MPH) that can not, under any circumstance, be slowed or stopped, or turned away from its constant path.

so the REAL question is:

what would happen if a force moving at a constant speed and on a constant path that could not be slowed or stopped was met by an object put in a set position that could not be moved from that set position under any circumstance whatsoever?

You get close to this concept in neutron stars.

The surface of a neutron star is so hard and dense that it makes a diamond look like the vacuum of outer space in comparison. It's so dense that a spoonful of it on Earth would weight loads of metric tons. You can only imagine how hard this material is, given its density. It's so hard that it's impossible to even imagine. Thus the surface of a neutron star is almost an immovable object.

On the other hand we have the gravity on the surface of a neutron star. The gravity is so strong that it quite visibly bends light. Any object, or even particle, near the surface will be slammed by gravity onto the surface so hard that it will break into its constituent subatomic particles and fuse into neutrons. While this is of course not "infinite" force, it's so many orders of magnitude stronger than anything we know that it's difficult to even visualize.

Where these two things come into play is when a rotating neutron star slows down due to loss of energy.

Neutron stars typically rotate very fast (even thousands of revolutions per second). This speed of rotation is so fast, in fact, that neutron stars are not spherical but spheroids. They are just so slightly squeezed so that their equatorial diameter is slightly larger than their polar diameter.

When the rotation of a neutron star slows down over millions of years, the gravity will start acting more and more strongly on the surface, pushing it to become more spherical. But as said, the star is so incredibly dense that almost no amount of force would be able to do that.

When the star slows down enough, however, gravity becomes too strong for the surface to withstand, and it gives way, even if so slightly. What happens here is that the entire star rearranges in a slightly more spherical shape in a tiny fraction of a second. Because of the forces involved, and the size of the star, and the speed at which this happens, this event is so energetic that it sends an enormous flash of energy to outer space. The event is called a "starquake".

the idea with the original question was to define the immovable object as one that could resist any force, and the irresistible force as one that would move any object, and that would set up the conundrum.  It's a piece of purely semantic deception:  The two definitions are incompatible in first place.  If there is such a thing as an object that cannot be moved by any force, then by definition there is no such thing as an irresistible force, and vice versa.

Second Law of Thermodynamics - Increased Entropy

The Second Law of Thermodynamics is commonly known as the Law of Increased Entropy [Decay]. While quantity remains the same (First Law), the quality of matter/energy deteriorates gradually over time. How so? Usable energy is inevitably used for productivity, growth and repair. In the process, usable energy is converted into unusable energy. Thus, usable energy is irretrievably lost in the form of unusable energy.

Nope. Wrong. 

Sure, we have no universal "point of reference". But we can pretty easily specify a point of reference based on our environment. I move in my room in relation to the walls. Car moves in relation to the road. Earth moves in relation to the sun. You get the idea.

Keep in mind that velocity (which you incorrectly used here) depends on a point of reference, otherwise its direction would be meaningless and it'd just be "speed".

So no "assumptions" needed here. We all know what implies an immovable object: it is something that would not "move" regardless of how large the context is; even if it is as big as our realm. Imagine our realm as a canvas. Now pick a corner. That's your point of reference.

Oh velocity, yeah...about that. Unstoppable force has a constant velocity? Wait a minute, it's a force, which means it has acceleration. Constant velocity is the farthest thing from it.

What does it mean to "stop" a force? Imagine two people arm wrestling, but neither wins. Or if a car hits the gas and brakes at the same time and manages to go at a constant V. That's "stopping" a force, just cancel it out with something of the same magnitude and opposite direction, reaching a constant V. Meaning that an unstoppable force never reaches a = 0, and V is never constant.

So what's the answer? Well, depends on the other variables. Is the immovable object also indestructible? It needs to be, otherwise its particles would move, defeating the whole concept. Does the unstoppable force change direction? It shouldn't, otherwise it could decelerate based on our point of reference.

The immovable object has infinite amount of force holding it in place, since it's an object and not able to move. Unstoppable force also has infinite amount of force. Assuming the two infinites to be the same magnitude, the net force should be 0, meaning that motion will not take place. Nothing will move. They will cancel each other out completely.

You may think that's a win for the immovable object but you'd be wrong. The immovable object will not longer be immovable. The slightest breeze in the same direction as the unstoppable force will easily move it, as if it had nothing holding it in place. You could even put a flashlight to it and it would start accelerating, as if it was completely free.

Hopefully that was more exciting for whoever decided to read along than this after this rather anti-climactic video. Great video, nevertheless.

Isaac Asimov already answered this question. Here is his explanation:

First of all, to answer a question we must know what the question is asking, and by that I mean that we must understand all the concepts involved in that question and make them very clear. In this case, we must know what an immovable object is, as well as what an unstoppable force is and make this concepts clear.

Like this video perfectly explained, an immovable object is an object that no matter what force you apply on it, you will never be able to accelerate it. An unstoppable force on the other hand, is a force that no matter what object it's applied on, it will always cause it to accelerate. Seems like we have a discrepancy here. By definition, the immovable object cannot be accelerated by this unstoppable force. However, also by definition this unstoppable force will always accelerate the immovable object. This doesn't make much sense...

So here's Asimov's conclusion:

A universe in which there exists such a thing as an irresistible force is, by definition, a universe which cannot also contain an immovable object. And a universe which contains an immovable object cannot, by definition, also contain an irresistible force. So the question is essentially meaningless: either the force is irresistible or the object is immovable, but not both.

Because in order for a object to shift into a opposite direction it was originally traveling in, it must stop first, then start moving again. For example, when you toss a ball into the air, before it travels back down towards you, it stops for a split second, suspended in mid-air, then travels back towards you. Or when you're driving a car. Hypothetically, you're driving and you shift into reverse while moving forward. Before the car can start traveling backwards, it stops for a split second, then starts moving backwards.

Principle of relativity says there's no way to detect your own velocity without a reference frame to move relative to. Usually we only deal with the reference frame of the earth, e.g. your car moves 80kph relative to the ground. How fast is that relative to the sun though? If our immovable object won't accelerate relative to the earth (it looks 'still'), it has to accelerate relative to the sun since the earth and the sun move. So now our 'immovable' object appears moving to someone on the sun.

But in relativity Einstein's first postulate states that it is impossible to perform an experiment to determine if you are moving with a constant velocity or stationary. This postulate is the foundation of special relativity and specifically states that it is equally valid to say you are moving relative to the object or the object is moving relative to you. Both are equally correct in physics and so there is no such thing as an immovable object. Just an object at rest in your reference frame.

I just thought about that and realized that while physical objects carrying the forces would interact with each other, the forces themselves would behave as described in this video, passing through each other unaffected. The objects would likely create nuclear fusion upon impact, intense enough to obliterate the earth, but the actual forces would likely continue out forever as rays. Thus most of the universe would probably be safe.

Therefore, there are two answers to the original question: a) the two objects/forces pass through each other without interacting, and/or b) the two objects/forces deccelerate each other to a dead halt and release an infinite explosion that would obliterate the entire visible universe in about 13.5byrs. In the latter case the objects themselves would neither be unstoppable nor immovable, but rather they would simply carry the unstoppable force as inertia. When they stop, the inertia continues on.

I also don't know of any physical object that doesn't interact with other physical objects. I didn't get the "divide by 0" result I was hoping for.  So ignoring gravity, but otherwise assuming that the objects act as any other matter, if the two objects collide at 100mph with infinite momentum, that would be INF/INF=1. Thus each object accelerates 1x its original velocity; in reverse, so effectively -1x, cancelling out both objects' momentum, which dissipates in a shockwave of infinite momentum.

Actually, if two objects are moving towards each other at the same speed, the "system" (the movement of both objects) has zero acceleration. If they collide and decelerate to zero velocity, then the deceleration would be equal and opposite, cancelling each other and equalling a "system" acceleration of, you guessed it: zero. In short, if two objects, immovable and unstoppable, were moving towards each other they would collide and maintain a "system" acceleration of zero = unstopped and unmoved!

Infinity/infinity is not always 1. Take for example the function f(x) = x^2/(x+1): as x becomes infinity, x^2 and (x+1) by themselves both become infinity, but so does f(x). On the other hand, the reciprocal of the function, (x+1)/(x^2) goes to 0. Therefore, Infinity/infinity could be 0, 1, or infinity, depending on the specific circumstance.

actually, that would be an acceleration in the opposite direction. Velocity is defined as speed with a direction, and acceleration is a change in velocity. Even if the speed is perfectly constant, if the direction changes, the velocity has changed, and therefore has accelerated. For example, an object moving in perfect circular motion (eg, a ball on a string spun around one's head) is actually constantly accelerating, even if the speed is constant.

Lastly, although I appreciate the point you were making with the last sentence, it wasn't the best example:

If the object is moving in a circle, then it will have one speed, but two velocities. Since velocity has a direction in addition to its magnitude, and that direction can only be denoted by positive or negative signs, then velocities must correspond only with straight lines. Two directions. If we use the circle example, then we are working with two dimensions.

A change in direction is a change in velocity, because velocity is a vector quantity. This means that not only does it have a magnitude, but it has a direction. "Forward" would be positive, and "backward" would be negative. You might be thinking of speed.

Since changing direction is changing velocity, then acceleration is defined as changing velocity. There's no need for redundancy.

Actually, an unacceleratable object doesn't need infinite energy or infinite mass, it only needs to be able to generate enough force to pass through anything unhindered. Granted, the amount of force necessary to pass through anything without slowing MAY be ungeneratable by traditional means, but it is not infinite. Therefore, an unacceleratable object COULD exist if it cannot be accelerated by anything in the universe, which would not require infinite energy, just more energy than anything else.

I always thought they would destroy each other because since the force unstoppable and the object is immovable, well, something's gotta give.

Finally, the final argument about both items becoming one can't exist. When both 'unacceleratable objects' hit each other, there will have to be an exchange of forces in the 'collision'. Both forces will have the same magnitude in opposite directions so one of 2 scenarios would have to happen: 1.They will cancel out & bring the objects to rest, or 2.If it's really impossible to change the speed, then at least their momentum (p=mv) will have to remain, so they will only change direction.

To say that there would be an 'immovable object' (in this situation an object whose acceleration is 0) would give infinite energy when not taking gravity into account is also wrong. An object can't just give off energy just like that simply because it's not accelerating. The only way for it to generate any source of energy would have to be through other means such as electromagnetism or another type of fusion or radiation, or another force acting upon it which would possibly require gravity.

You can't just say that an 'unstoppable force' and an 'immovable object' are the same. To say that an object and a force are the same is not correct. A force acts on an object. In any case, if F=ma, a situation where a=0, the Force would have to equal zero and therefore this theory fails. Nevertheless, in situations where F=∞ and m=∞, require different formulas (as in the equations of planetary motion) so this theory also fails regardless.

You're completely and utterly incorrect. The entire point of relativity is that when you start moving relative to, say, the Earth, the Earth IS moving relative to you. They're both frames of reference that are equally valid. We like to think in terms of the Earth's reference frame, because save for a handful of us, no one has really been exempt from it, but that doesn't make the Earth's frame 'right.'  All frames of reference are 'right' but there is no universal one.

I'm no physicist, but I think relativity is partially derived from the fact that there is no frame of reference.  You and I feel like we're sitting still at the pc but in reality we're hurling extremely fast around the sun.  We're just still relative to the earth beneath us.  You can't say that the sun is still because it too (along with the rest of the solar system) is orbiting.  So is the milky way galaxy.  If there ever was anything that was absolutely motionless, noone knows of it.

Are you saying that when you're sitting in a car on a perfectly smooth road and holding your hand perfectly still, that it's not moving?
To YOU, your hand is perfectly still. It's not moving RELATIVE to you (to your frame of reference), but it IS moving.
RELATIVE to the earth, it's moving with the car.
Even beyond that, it's moving with the rotation of the earth, and with the revolution of the earth around the sun, and with the revolution of the sol system around the galaxy.

No, that doesn't mean 1 = 2, cause you can't cancel out infinite like that. When you do that, you're really multiplying both sides by ∞, but ∞/∞ is not 1 but instead is undefined, so 1 ∞/∞ = 2 ∞/∞ does not reduce to 1=2 any more than 1*0=2*0 reduces to 1=2.

Dividing and multiplying infinite is well defined, and it's critical in a lot of areas of physics. It's just not the same rules as numbers in the "real numbers" set so if you apply it naively you get contradictions.

"Not removable"?
There is a single hole in the line y = x/x at x = 0. You could define the function to be defined at x = 0 by saying that f(0) = 1 as a piecewise function and thus make the whole function continuous across the whole domain.
The very act of doing just that means it's by definition a removeable discontinuity.

Sorry, I didn't mean after; I meant take the displacement-time graph, and measure the gradient of the tangent at 0.

If s = 0, then it is constant, and so ds/dt is also 0, hence the velocity is zero.
Measuring the gradient after differentiation at 0 is weird.

I think you should have a little look at differential calculus.  v = s/t only for displacement (s, that is distance in a direction) that is a linear function of time.  More accurately, v = ds/dt, the derivative of s with respect to t.  And that's already found as a limit as the change in time tends towards zero (i.e. at any given instant) so it all works.

It's equivalent to finding the gradient of a tangent to the s/t graph at the point you want.

Slower-than-c speeds in material substances represent absorption and re-radiation delays between atoms, or rather, the superposition of the incident sinusoidally oscillating fields and the re-radiated oscillating fields. So, the wave front in media, which is what you are talking about, is a net resultant wave whose crests travel at a speed slower than c. However, photons and individual electromagnetic waves travel at c. Always.

Here's why an immovable force can not meet an unstoppable force: in order for one to exist, the other can not. If there is an immovable object, then it can stop any force by definition, meaning that there would be no such thing as an unstoppable force. The converse is also true. If there is an unstoppable force, then it can move all objects, meaning there is no such thing as an immovable object.

No. I was specifically taught this in physics. Deceleration is not a physics term, it's more literary. Acceleration is defined by a change in velocity. Thus whether that is positive or negative, it is changing. It can be expressed as either + or -m/s^2. Velocity is a change in position over time. Also negative or positive. You would not call that 'delocity'. Both are also vectors, so direction matters. You can't say 'deceleration' if the only thing changing is direction.

But if the two objects phased together, keeping their respective masses, and the center of the masses came together at the same point, what would happen? Newton's Law of Gravitation, F=Gm1m2/d2, states that the force of gravity on an object is indirectly proportional to the square of the distance between the two objects. If the center of the masses hit the same point, the distance between them would be zero, resulting in a zero on the bottom of the equation, which is mathematically impossible.

If they did crash, wouldn't they exert an infinite amount of force on each other, therefore pushing them in opposite directions? Because F=infinity•A, it would take an infinite force to move it, and it would exert infinite force on what it hits.

The human brain has an amazing ability to accommodate our perception of reality to our expectations. It's a basic survival thing. Makes things easier. it's a question of inertial reference frames. acceleration is referred to as absolute but only because an object accelerates relative to all inertial frames or none. inertial frames (frames that move with constant velocity) are frames in which Newton's 1st Law (an object not subjected to a force will not accelerate) holds, so applying a force to yourself (ignoring the violation of conservation of energy) would make you accelerate absolutely, rather than relative to anything

moving in one direction, and moving at the same speed in the other direction, are not the same velocity.  example, the box moving towards the right side of the video might have a velocity of 100; one moving towards the left, has a velocity of *negative* 100.  so, if the two boxes collided, and then moved in the same direction, one box must have quickly DEcelerated (negative acceleration, but technically acceleration nonetheless) to 0 (standing still), then quickly accelerated by 100.

If x equals ten divided by zero, then x times zero equals ten, but there is no x that, multiplied by zero, gives ten (or any other number than zero). If instead of x=10/0 we have x=0/0, then every x satisfies the question 'what number x, multiplied by zero, gives zero?'

The theory of relativity shows how movement (or anything else for the matter) is based on perspective. If we are moving toward something or past it at constant velocity, we see that the other object is moving toward us or past us but to an observer, they see us moving. However, whose perspective is right? The answer is that they are both right, and it just depends on whose perspective you choose to see it from. In the end, the math adds up.

To answer your first question, no.  An unstoppable force, or rather an unacceleratable mass with some velocity already, cannot be redirected if its velocity stays the same.  Velocity includes both speed AND direction, so to change the direction would change the velocity, even if the speed was the same.  Changing the velocity means it has been accelerated, and therefore isn't really unacceleratable.
tl;dr - changing direction IS changing the velocity, so it isn't unmovable.

First off, it's not "is 0" when you divide a constant by infinity. However, it is a limit that APPROACHES 0.

Example: (The sum of all positive even numbers)/(Sum of all positive numbers)
The first "infinity" is significantly smaller than the second "infinity" because the second includes EVERY number, rather than just the evens.

x/infinite = 0
x/x = 1

So which is it? It could be any of the 3, or something completely different.

The theory of relativity states, that movement is relative to the system it is compared to. The best system one could compare a movement to is one's own body. Therefore, taking the own body as a reference point, said body is an unmovable object, logically speaking. Therefore, from a logical point of view, there are objects that do not [visibly] move in relation to themselves. Every object is an unmovable one as long as it itself is the system it is compared to.

what happens when an infinite force is applied to an object of infinite mass?

Yikes, I hope I can fit it in. 2nd law says entropy (disorder) increases with time. Example, start with a jigsaw in it's box with all the pieces in the right places. High state of order (low entropy). Shake the box. Pieces (most likely) end in a less ordered configuration (higher entropy). Trick is, it is possible (although of course unlikely) that you might shake the box and all the pieces end up in the right place. When that happens the 2nd law has been broken.

In conventional physics "changing direction" requires deceleration. Imagine an object moving 50kph along some arbitrarily determined X axis. In order for this object to change direction and move at 50kph in, say, the direction of the "Y" axis, it would have to be decelerated in the direction of the X axis and would have to be accelerated along the Y axis.

It is for this reason that physicists refer to any change in direction as acceleration, even if speed remains constant.

All the photons are quickly absorbed by your surroundings.  The only reason a room is "lit up" is because you have a constant source of photons, a tiny percentage of which is reflected from the objects in the room and into your eye. But, yeah, the photons either get absorbed or reflected, then absorbed.

Here's an abridged version of this video:

An immovable object must have infinite mass. We can derive this from Newton's second law F=ma, or better a=F/m. If mass is infinite, then the F/m will always theoretically equal 0, thus a=0. 
An unstoppable force is assumed to be an object who's velocity can not be changed. Changing velocities always requires some acceleration to be applied by a force. Therefore no matter how hard we push on it, we can never change its velocity, so a=0.
Both have a=0!

When he says "reference frame" he means something like a 3d Cartesian coordinate system.  If you define your own location to be (0,0,0), then in that coordinate system you cannot move, so any motion must be of other objects.  You can put (0,0,0) anywhere you choose, as long as it isn't accelerating.  Any choice of inertial reference frame is valid, and none of them are the "real" reference frame.  That's what relativity is all about.

Infinity doesn't work that way. In fact, infinity over infinity can equal any real number. For example, what is the slope of the line 4x+1/x as x tends to infinity? The equation becomes (4*infinity + 1)/(infinity). The 1 makes no difference, but 4*infinity still equals infinity. Thus, in this case, infinity divided by infinity equals 4 (which is what we know the slope of the line will approach. Graph it if you're unconvinced.).

Actually that's technically wrong. Metal is defined by electronic behavior and not an absolute elemental property. Different elements can have different allotropes. Carbon is usually non-metal. However the allotropes of carbon nanotubes and also graphene, (both pure carbon), behave as a metal. Some CNTs are actually called "metallic", while other are semiconductors. But yes, diamond is NOT metal because there's no electron delocalization, and it's an  insulator w/ very low electron conductivity.

Any element heavier (i.e., having more protons its nucleus) than helium are considered metals in astrophysical terms. Diamonds are actually made of carbon in an incredibly firm lattice structure. Carbon is not a metal - it's in a group on the periodic table known (rather simply) as non-metals. And while diamonds may be 'harder' than metal, they're not as 'strong' - because of the rigid lattice that the carbon forms, diamonds are quite brittle, while metals are flexible. In addition, metals need to conduct electricity in some form, and diamonds (as far as I know) do not. Hope this clears some things up.

Not correct. The kinetic energy of the crash is proportionate to the square of the impact speed. Two cars crashing into each other at 50mph each is far less severe than a 100mph car crashing into a wall.

A universe in which there exists such a thing as an irresistible force is, by definition, a universe which cannot also contain an immovable object. And a universe which contains an immovable object cannot, by definition, also contain an irresistible force. So the question is essentially meaningless: either the force is irresistible or the object is immovable, but not both.

This is so entirely the wrong answer that it leaves me flabbergasted.  The question is internally self contradictory. It need not refer to anything in any imaginable universe in order to be contradictory. The term ‘immovable object’ (in the context of the question) refers to the resistibility to all conceivable forces and the term ‘irresistible force’ refers to the movability of all conceivable objects. It’s astounding to me that this is not obvious with just a little thought.
